titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Ramón Carulla Papers, 1971-1996, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Stephanie Ashley

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Stephanie Ashley, 2002

change.item: Finding aid updated from EAD v. 1.0 to v. 2002 by Stephanie Ashley

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The Ramón Carulla papers contain letters, photographs, printed material, an interview, sketchbooks, and artwork documenting the career of Cuban American painter Ramón Carulla.
did.langmaterial: The records are in English and Spanish.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ramón Carulla was born in Havana, Cuba in 1938. In 1946 he moved to Miami with his father to attend public school, returning to Havana in 1953 to complete his schooling. In 1963 he began painting and had his first one-man show in 1967 at the Bacardi Gallery in Miami, where he had settled two years earlier. Although his work was initially abstract Carulla had moved towards figurative art by the late 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection dates from 1971-1996, comprises 0.3 linear feet, and provides scattered documentation of the career of Cuban American painter Ramón Carulla. The collection contains letters to Carulla from artists and others; writings by others for and about Carulla; the transcript of an interview with Carulla; photographs of Carulla, friends, and his artwork; two sketchbooks; a painting; and printed matter including exhibition announcements and catalogs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into five series:

list.item: Series 1: Letters and Biographical Material, 1971-1996 (box 1, 3 folders)
Series 2: Writings About Carulla and Interview, 1986-1995, undated (box 1, 3 folders)

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following index terms. People, families and organizations are listed under "Names" when they are creators or contributors and under "Subjects" when they are the topic of collection contents.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the Archives of American Art by Ramón Carulla in 1997.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Use requires an appointment and is limited to the Washington, D.C. research facility.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Ramón Carulla papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ramón Carulla papers, 1971-1996. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Rosa Fernández in 1998.

scopecontent.p: This series contains letters to Carulla from friends and artists including Fernando Luis and mail art from Miguel Cubiles. There are also letters from others concerning business such as exhibitions and gifts of Carulla's work.

did.unittitle: Letters from Friends and Artists, 1971-1996, undated
Letters Concerning Exhibitions and Other Business, 1987-1995
Writings About Carulla and Interview, 1986-1995, undated

scopecontent.p: Essays on Carulla found here include The Men Under the Hats by Giulio Blanc, Ramón Carulla: The Delicate Look of Madness by Alicia M. Menendez, and an essay by Karen Kundsen of the Detroit Art Institute.

did.unittitle: Essays on Carulla by Art Historians, 1992, 1994, undated
Poem, A Ramón Carulla, by Humberto J. Figueras, 1995
Transcript (in Spanish) of an Interview of Carulla by Felix Beltran, 1986
Exhibition Announcements, Catalogs, and Press Releases, 1989-1994, undated

scopecontent.p: Photographs of Carulla with friends and family include Miguel Cubiles, José Luis Cuevas, Andres Valerio, Carlos Mérida, and Carlos Carulla.
